definition:
Let $\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B}$ be two . Then a *$*$-homomorphism*
$\phi_*:\mathcal{A} \longrightarrow \mathcal{B}$ is defined as a
C\*-algebra homomorphism $\phi:\mathcal{A}  \to \mathcal{B}$ which
respects involutions, that is:

$$\phi(a^{*_{\mathcal{A}}}) = \phi(a)^{*_{\mathcal{B}}},\quad\mbox{ for any } a \in \mathcal{A}.$$

If ‘by abuse of notation’ one uses $*$ to denote both $*_{\mathcal{A}}$
and $*_{\mathcal{B}}$, then any $*$-homomorphism $\phi$ commutes with
$*$, i.e., $\phi*=*\phi$. Homomorphisms between $C^*$-algebras are .

The category $\mathcal{C}$ whose objects are $C^*$-algebras and whose
morphisms are $*$-homomorphisms is called the *category of
$C^*$-algebras* or the *$C^*$-algebra category*.

[9]{}

Kustermans, J., C\*-algebraic Quantum Groups arising from Algebraic
Quantum Groups, Ph.D. Thesis, K.U.Leuven, 1997.

Sheu, A.J.L., Compact Quantum Groups and Groupoid C\*-Algebras, J.
Funct. Analysis 144 (1997), 371-393.
